ORAL ANSWERS TO QUESTIONS

HDB RENTAL FLAT TENANTS IN ARREARS


    1. Mr Chng Hee Kok asked the Minister for National Development if the Housing and Development Board will indicate the number of cases of tenants of rental flats who are in arrears of rent for six months or more.

     The Minister for National Development (Mr S. Dhanabalan): Mr Speaker, Sir, the number of tenants of rental flats who are in arrears of rent for six months or more is about 1,990 cases. This is as at 31st December 1987. This makes up 2.7% of the total rental units occupied. The total rental units occupied is 74,243. The actual amount owed is about $1.7 million or 27.9% of the total monthly rental collectable. The rental arrears come mainly from the 1-room and 2-room rental flat tenants.

     Mr Philip Tan Tee Yong (Paya Lebar): Sir, could the Minister tell the House the steps HDB will take to assist those who are in arrears of rent and those who are in arrears of instalment payments?

     Mr Dhanabalan: Mr Speaker, Sir, for tenants of HDB flats who are in arrears of rent, first of all, HDB can assist by allowing them to pay their arrears by instalments. If they happen to occupy a 3-room rental flat - there are not many but there are some who are in 3-room rental flats - then they will be allowed to sublet one of the rooms and supplement their income, thus enabling them to pay their rental. In some cases, they can be helped by allowing them to do some home-based work in the flat to help them generate additional income to pay their rents. When all these measures are not sufficient and they happen to occupy large flats, 3- or 4-room rental flats, then they will have to transfer to smaller flats.

    In the case of mortgage loan repayments, those who are in arrears of instalment payments, the measures are similar. First of all, they will be allowed to reschedule their loans if it can be shown that they can meet their new schedule. In some cases, they may have taken loans for 10 years or 12 years on the basis of their

Column: 1046

financial circumstances at the time they bought the flat and now find that they cannot meet a 10- or 12-year loan repayment schedule. In such cases, we can extend the loan repayment schedule up to 25 years to enable them to pay.

    We can also allow, and HDB does allow, purchasers of HDB flats to rent out one of their rooms for additional income. In some cases, a balooning repayment schedule will be of assistance. In such cases, we will reschedule their loans. And in some cases, they may have to sell their flat, if it is a 5-room flat or 4-room flat, and purchase a smaller flat. In other extreme cases, they may not be able to purchase a flat at all. They may have to move to a rental flat.

    In all these cases, I have told HDB that if these people have to downgrade they should be offered an alternative flat immediately so that they are not in a position where they have no place to live.

    I think Members, from their own experience, know by now that the people who cannot pay or are in arrears fall into various categories. There are those who cannot be helped by any of the measures that I have mentioned. These are mostly old people, with very low income, in poor health, maybe with children who are very ill. Quite a few have children who have mental problems. And they normally live in 1-room or 2-room rental flats. HDB has identified about 500 such cases which they think are genuine, financially strapped, cases. These cases were referred to the Ministry of Community Development. Further checks by MCD showed that not all of them are not able to pay. Some, in fact, as soon as MCD approached them said that they had no problem. They could get their children to pay or they had other sources. And they paid up.

    But there are genuine hardship cases who cannot be helped by any of the measures that I have mentioned and who really cannot afford to pay the rent. These are basically people living in 1-room rental flats. At present, the measures that we have to assist them are rather ad hoc. For those who qualify for public assistance, we refer them to MCD. HDB does try to refer them to other welfare agencies, private charities, but we do not have a proper

Column: 1047

system of dealing with these cases. I have asked the HDB to work together with MCD to come out with a scheme that can assist this small number who genuinely cannot afford to pay even the rent of a 1-room rental flat.

    There is another category who have genuine financial difficulties who can be helped with the measures that I have just mentioned. With some assistance, they can continue to occupy the rental or purchase flat that they now occupy. Others may require more time, as I mentioned. Their financial circumstances at the time they bought the flat may be different from what it is now. But if there is enough evidence that either they have got a new job or a son is coming out of NS and is starting work or a daughter is starting work, in other words, if they can show that they can meet the arrears if it is rescheduled, HDB will certainly consider. In fact, it will allow such rescheduling. I want to give an assurance to Members that this rescheduling will be allowed at any stage of the proceedings, as long as they can show quite clearly that they are able to meet such a rescheduled payment of a loan or arrears of rental. But after months of trying and discussions with HDB, if there is really no alternative and there seems to be no end to the financial problems that they have and it is quite clear that their financial circumstances have changed such that they cannot continue to occupy a 4- or 5-room purchase flat or even a 3-room purchase flat, then I am afraid that they will have to consider moving to either a rental flat or moving to a smaller purchase flat.

    There are other cases which appear to have financial difficulties who cannot meet payments. But this is basically because of very poor budgetting habits, gambling, drunkenness and so on. In some cases, they may find that the measures that HDB has will be able to assist them. But HDB will in all these cases press hard for payment. HDB does not really have the manpower resources to counsel these people or to help them. They have to help themselves. From all the evidence, they have sufficient income to meet the

Column: 1048

payments but they do not have the right priorities or financial discipline. They must learn financial discipline.

     Mr Chng Hee Kok (Radin Mas): Sir, will the Minister confirm that formal measures or schemes will be announced once the HDB has completed its study with the MCD?

     Mr Dhanabalan: Sir, if the Member is referring to the few genuine cases that cannot even meet the rental payments, yes, of course, when we have completed our studies, I will announce it.

     Dr Koh Lam Son (Telok Blangah): Sir, under what circumstances, if any, will HDB evict a tenant who is in arrears of rent?

     Mr Dhanabalan: When all the measures that I have spelt out have been tried and they still cannot pay and they do not want to downgrade or their incomes are obviously sufficient but because of lack of financial discipline they are not able to meet, HDB will evict.

     Dr Augustine H.H. Tan (Whampoa): Mr Speaker, Sir, will the HDB consider helping out with relocation expenses in the event of these hardship cases having to be relocated to smaller flats?

     Mr Dhanabalan: I am afraid we have no such scheme at the present moment but there are enough charities in Singapore who can help genuine cases.

AYER RAJAH EXPRESSWAY
(Development progress)


    2. Encik Abbas Abu Amin asked the Minister for National Development what is the progress on the development of Ayer Rajah Expressway, particularly the portion between the junction of Alexandra Road/Ayer Rajah Road and the junction of Clementi Road/Ayer Rajah Road; whether sufficient overhead bridges are built along the portion; and whether bus-stops are located near the Housing and Development Board Ayer Rajah Estate.

     Mr Dhanabalan: Sir, the construction of the Ayer Rajah Expressway (AYE) which runs from Shenton Way in the east to Jurong Town Hall Road in the west is being built in phases.

Column: 1049



    The Keppel Viaduct, part of the expressway, was opened to traffic in September 1985. The stretch from the viaduct to Alexandra Road was opened to traffic in May 1986.

    The stretch of the expressway from Alexandra Road to Jurong Town Hall Road, which involves the upgrading of the existing Ayer Rajah Road and Upper Ayer Rajah Road to expressway standards, will be completed by May 1988.

    Five pedestrian overhead bridges and one pedestrian underpass will be provided along the stretch of the expressway between Alexandra Road and Clementi Road. These crossings are sufficient to allow for safe movement of pedestrians across the expressway.

    To ensure safe operation of the expressway, the existing pair of bus stops in front of the HDB Ayer Rajah Estate will be resited eastwards to the Buona Vista Interchange area. Walking distance for some residents to these bus stops will increase by up to 250 metres. This is about four minutes' walk. It is not possible to retain the bus stops at their present locations without compromising the safe operation of the expressway.

Column: 1049

PASIR PANJANG SECONDARY AND LABRADOR PRIMARY SCHOOLS
(Enrolment patterns)


    3. Encik Abbas Abu Amin asked the Minister for Education (a) if he will indicate (i) the enrolment patterns of Pasir Panjang Secondary School and Labrador Primary School and (ii) the breakdowns of ethnic groups attending these schools for the years 1984, 1985, 1986 and 1987; and (b) whether there are plans to renovate and improve the facilities in these two schools.

     The Parliamentary Secretary to the Minister for Education (Mr Tang Guan Seng)(for the Minister for Education): Mr Speaker, Sir, I am answering on behalf of my Minister.

    Sir, I will be forwarding the tables on the enrolment patterns for Pasir Panjang Secondary and Labrador Primary Schools by year and ethnic group to the Member for Pasir Panjang.

Column: 1050



    The overall enrolments in both schools have been declining. Our plan is to phase out Labrador Primary School and transfer the remaining 172 pupils to Jagoh Primary School in January 1989. If the enrolment for Pasir Panjang Secondary School continues to decline, plans will be made to close the school in the next 1-2 years.

    In view of the impending development, there is no necessity to renovate these two schools.

Column: 1050

LITTERING
(Control measures)


    4. Dr Koh Lam Son asked the Minister for the Environment whether his Ministry has identified the places where littering occurs habitually and what measures are being taken to control littering in such places.

     The Minister for the Environment (Dr Ahmad Mattar): Mr Speaker, Sir, littering usually occurs in places with a high population density or high level of human activity. Examples of these areas are HDB estates, major pedestrian thoroughfares, bus stops, parks and beaches.

    My Ministry together with the HDB and the Parks & Recreation Department held a "No Sweeping Day" on 5th March 1988 to demonstrate to the people the extent of littering that still persists in Singapore. The exercise also showed clearly the specific areas that are litter prone.

    Sir, I have brought with me a set of photographs showing the extent of littering in these places. I have deposited a set in the Parliament Library for Members to see.

    My Ministry will continue with its educational efforts to get members of the public to cooperate in keeping such places litter free. Enforcement will continue to be taken against those who persist in their anti-social behaviour.

     Dr Koh Lam Son (Telok Blangah): Sir, may I ask the Minister whether it is a good idea perhaps to monitor those places which are habitually littered, and apply your enforcement actions, educational programme, just on those places. As an example, in the Telok Blangah Estate, we have one or two places, the rental blocks

Column: 1051

which are habitually littered. If the Ministry could put up more penalty signs, the anti-littering signs, monitor the situation and apply enforcement action there, I think perhaps we can clear up the problem.

     Dr Ahmad Mattar: Mr Speaker, Sir, I could not agree with the Member more. We will do that.

     Mr S. Chandra Das (Chong Boon): Sir, the Minister has identified the HDB estates as a litter-prone area. Would the Minister for the Environment be prepared to give town councils when they are established a more effective role in litter control?

     Dr Ahmad Mattar: Sir, the answer is yes. But it is hard for me to say at this point of time whether Town Councils will be a more efficient organization to control littering offences. All I can say now is that where the Town Councils are successful in communicating closely with residents of the estates under their charge and through persuasion and cooperation by the residents in these estates themselves, there should be every confidence that in such estates there would be fewer cases of littering offences and fewer litterbugs eventually.

Column: 1051

ANTI-LITTERING CAMPAIGN
(Effectiveness of)


    5. Mr Yeo Choo Kok asked the Minister for the Environment (a) what is his Ministry's assessment of the effectiveness of the Anti-Littering Campaign in the past 20 years; (b) what was the percentage of foreigners in the 8,702 summonses issued to offenders in 1987; and (c) how many were foreigners out of the 190 motorists and their passengers who were fined a total of $26,200 in the same year.

     Dr Ahmad Mattar: Mr Speaker, Sir, generally Singaporeans are aware that littering is an offence. Many litter under cover of darkness, for example, inside cinemas, throwing litter out of flats mostly in the nights. A motorist who throws out a cigarette butt usually does it by sliding his hands slowly down the side of the car hoping that he would not be detected. There are also many who are bothered

Column: 1052

when they come across a place accumulated with refuse strewn all over. They get upset when they come across a littered beach and disgusted when they have to sit through a movie in a littered cinema.

    Last year, Sir, my Ministry received a total of 33 complaints from members of the public on littering and there were seven letters to the press complaining about littering. On the other hand, Sir, there are also people who would reason to themselves that the piece of litter that they drop on the ground would not do any harm, or they would say to themselves, "The place is already littered. This piece of litter which I am about to drop will not make the place any worse."

    The past 20 years, Sir, has definitely brought about greater awareness amongst our population that littering and other anti-social acts, such as spitting, urinating in lifts, are undesirable acts. The public, in general, know what they should do and what they should not. What we would like to do now, Sir, is to encourage everyone to make a personal effort to refrain from littering. Adults will be asked to set a good example to their children and children could also set a good example to the adults. We hope to see people refrain from littering as a nature of habit or through good sense of social responsibility rather than through fear of enforcement.

    Sir, the Member for Delta wants to know the percentage of foreigners in the 8,702 summonses issued to offenders in 1987. Sir, the answer is 536 or 6.2% of the offenders issued with summonses last year were foreigners.

    The Member also wants to know the number of foreigners there were in the 190 motorists and their passengers who were fined a total of $26,200 for littering last year. Sir, the answer is 10 or 5.3%.

     Mr Yeo Choo Kok (Delta): Sir, can the Minister tell the House who these foreigners are? Are they visitors, tourists or workers?

     Dr Ahmad Mattar: Sir, the foreigners booked last year were either workers or residents in Singapore. Tourists are usually given a word of advice if they are caught littering in public places.

Column: 1053

INTEGRATED CIVIL DEFENCE EXERCISE


    6. Dr Koh Lam Son asked the Minister for Home Affairs whether his Ministry will in the near future conduct an integrated civil defence exercise involving rescue, food and water rations, transport, blood donation and other civil defence activities.

     The Minister of State for Home Affairs (Dr Lee Boon Yang)(for the Minister for Home Affairs): Mr Speaker, Sir, since November 1985, we have conducted a series of emergency exercises in various constituencies. These exercises provide an opportunity for our people to learn how to cope with emergencies. They are part of our Total Defence effort.

    To date, we have conducted three Emergency Food Exercises in 21 constituencies, two Water Exercises in 11 constituencies, two Blood Collection Exercises in seven constituencies, one Transportation Exercise in three constituencies, nine Rescue Exercises in nine constituencies and one Public MRT Shelter Exercise. Our plan is to complete the exercises for the remaining constituencies over the next 4-5 years so that every Singaporean will have an opportunity to take part in these exercises.

    The public's active participation in the exercises has been good. In the Emergency Food Exercise conducted six months ago in 15 constituencies, some 200,000 residents from 57,000 households took part. In the most recent Civil Defence Shelter Exercise at the Tiong Bahru MRT Station, 4,500 residents participated on a Sunday morning.

    We do plan to integrate the different exercises gradually over the next 4-5 years. For a start, the Food and Water Exercises will be conducted together in the same constituencies next year. More integrated exercises will be carried out in subsequent years.

Column: 1053

VAGABONDS


    7. Dr Koh Lam Son asked the Minister for Community Development what is the latest figure of reported vagabonds and what is his Ministry doing to assist such unfortunate Singaporeans.

Column: 1054



     The Minister for Community Development (Mr Wong Kan Seng): Sir, a total of 232 beggars and vagrants were reported to the Ministry in 1987. The numbers reported to the Ministry for the past three years are: 1985 - 254; 1986 - 228; 1987 - 232. So on average there has been 20 cases per month reported to the Ministry. Many of these cases reported were from members of the public and they refer to the same persons sighted at different places at different times.

    The Ministry's Beggar Control Squad conducted 61 operations in 1987 and they picked up 145 beggars and vagrants. In 1985 they picked up 247 and in 1986 they picked up 152. I will ask the Clerk to circulate these numbers later to you.

    The beggars and vagrants picked up by the Beggar Control Squad are admitted to the Ministry's Welfare Homes pending social inquiries into their background. Such inquiries, which have to be conducted within one month to enable the Director of Social Welfare to ensure that only destitute persons within the meaning of the Destitute Persons Act (DPA) are required to reside in the Welfare Homes.

    Those with proper places of abode or means of subsistence are discharged to their families, relatives or other care persons with a warning.

    The Welfare Homes provide shelter, care and rehabilitation.

    Sir, there are really limitations as to what we can do for the destitutes as many of them have psychiatric or suffered from psychiatric disorders, physical disabilities, alcoholism and chronic illnesses like hypertension, diabetes and cardiac problem.

    Those who are fit for open employment outside the Home are placed on day release scheme. They go out to work and return to the Home in the evenings. Those fit for light duties are placed in sheltered workshops or on home maintenance programmes. The rest are kept socially active through a series of programmes ranging from Qigong, gardening, indoor games, outing, tailoring, sewing to hair dressing and handicraft.

Column: 1055



    The Ministry through its welfare service supports the efforts of the Welfare Homes by helping the residents to adjust to institutional life, helping the residents to maintain a fair standard of personal hygiene and grooming, sustaining a pool of volunteers to befriend, advise and counsel the residents through regular visits, providing aftercare for residents who are discharged from the Homes. They find employment for them or help to patch up relationships with their families.

    The Ministry will introduce legislation to repeal and to re-enact the existing Destitute Persons Act to make it current and relevant. Under the Destitute Persons Act, beggars and vagrants are treated as destitute persons. Begging is regarded as a social problem.

    But able-bodied beggars and vagrants, including absconders and those who are recalcitrants, are more in need of discipline than care. The DPA is not meant to cater for this type of beggars and vagrants. Some of the beggars apprehended in 1987 had cash in their possession amounting to between $250 and $780. Two of them even have bank accounts. One of them has about $29,000 and the other $132,000.

    The proposed amendments will differentiate between the able-bodied beggars and vagrants and those who beg because circumstances offer them no alternative. Habitual beggars will be charged in court.

     Dr Wang Kai Yuen (Bukit Timah): Among these habitual vagabonds, are there any non-resident Singaporeans who commute to Singapore to ply their trade?

     Mr Wong Kan Seng: Yes, there are some of these whom we call "seasonal beggars". They come here at a time when we have a festive occasion and they go off after the festive occasion. There are such people and if we find them in places of worship or hawker centres and so on, we work with the Immigration Department to send them back.

     Dr Koh Lam Son: How many of these vagabonds are new cases and how many are repeat cases, ie, the people whom you

Column: 1056

cannot help and they go back into the streets? Is it true that if a vagrant is found to have a home address, the Ministry will then not give him or her any assistance?

     Mr Wong Kan Seng: Sir, I do not have the details of how many were first-time beggars and vagabonds and repeat offenders like this. But if the Member is interested, I will try to dig them out for him. For those, as I said, with a habitual place of abode or relatives or with families, after social inquiries, that means after investigation into their background and if they are able to be returned to their families, we will make an effort to return them.

Column: 1056

1987 ECONOMIC SURVEY OF SINGPORE
(Copyright)


    8. Mr Chng Hee Kok asked the Minister for Trade and Industry why the 1987 Economic Survey of Singapore is accorded copyright protection which effectively discourages the wider dissemination of the information contained in the report.

     The Minister for Trade and Industry (BG Lee Hsien Loong): Mr Speaker, Sir, dissemination of the information in the Economic Survey has never been a problem. The international practice is to copyright publications of this nature. Annual reports and surveys published by organizations like the IMF and World Bank are invariably copyrighted.

    Even though the Survey has been copyrighted, portions can be reproduced with prior permission from MTI. This is how the newspapers pick up the major facts in the report. Besides this, the Copyright Act also allows anyone to copy parts of the Survey for his personal use.

     Mr Chng Hee Kok: First, will the Minister confirm that this copyright notice is not found in the previous year's Economic Surveys? Second, who gets the profit from the sale of the Economic Survey of Singapore?

     BG Lee Hsien Loong: On the first point, it is true the previous Economic Surveys were not copyrighted but in all previous years the Quarterly Surveys which are published in the first, second and third quarters have been copy-righted. So the

Column: 1057

Annual Survey was left out as an anomaly which has now been put right.

    As for who gets the profits from the sale, I do not know whether any money accrues, but I should imagine either the printers get their share or its goes back to Consolidated accounts. Anyway, MTI does not keep the money.

     Mr Chng Hee Kok: But the Economic Survey of Singapore is licensed by the MTI. So I assume some money must have gone back to the MTI.

     BG Lee Hsien Loong: Mr Speaker, Sir, I do not think that is a Government fiscal practice.

Column: 1057

COMPLAINTS AGAINST TRAVEL AGENTS


    9. Mr Yeo Choo Kok asked the Minister for Trade and Industry (a) how many licensed travel agents there are to date; (b) how many complaints have been made by local tourists to the Singapore Tourist Promotion Board against travel agents for not adhering to agreed programmes and services abroad since 1st January, 1987; (c) what action has been taken against these agents; and (d) whether the STPB has any plan to train more tourist guides.

     BG Lee Hsien Loong: Mr Speaker, Sir, there are 392 licensed travel agents as at 12th March this year.

    Between 1st January 1987 and 12th March this year, STPB has received 44 complaints from local tourists concerning overseas tours that were not conducted in accordance with agreed terms and conditions.

    All the 44 complaints received were investigated by the STPB. Investigations on 35 of the complaints have been completed. Of these, 27 were established to be valid. Generally, the problems were due to lapses in coordination between the local and overseas tour operators. For all the 27 cases, the local travel agents concerned were made to refund or pay compensation to the complainants. In addition, the travel agents were warned to ensure that their overseas ground operators adhere to the terms and conditions of the tour as contracted, and to give proper pre-tour briefings to their clients.

Column: 1058



    So far, no travel agent has been prosecuted by STPB for such complaints. The problem is not a serious one because more than 4 million overseas trips were made by Singaporeans and permanent residents in 1987, many of whom had probably gone on organized tours, and there were only 44 complaints. Nevertheless, STPB is closely monitoring the situation and local tour operators will be constantly reminded to work more closely with their overseas tour operators to minimize such incidents.

    To date, STPB has conducted 22 Basic Tourist Guide courses. Currently, there are 544 licensed tourist guides in Singapore and they are conversant in one or more of 16 languages. STPB plans to train about 60-80 guides each year.

Column: 1058

MEDISAVE
(Abuse)


    10. Mr Chew Heng Ching asked the Acting Minister for Health whether the Medisave Audit Review Committee set up in December 1987 has identified cases of abuse in the use of Medisave and, if so, what actions will be taken to prevent these abuses from happening again.

     The Acting Minister for Health (Mr Yeo Cheow Tong): Mr Speaker, Sir, the Medisave Audit Review Committee was set up in December 1987 to review audit reports on the financial compliance and medical aspects of Medisave claims. It also monitors Medisave spending patterns to see if any trends emerge.

    The CPF audit team has recently completed an audit of Medisave claims in NUH and three Government hospitals. They evaluated the system of internal control, and carried out checks on compliance with the claims procedure and guidelines as well as on the accuracy of the documents and records.

    The audit showed that there were a few minor administrative errors in some of the Medisave claims. There were, however, no cases of abuse detected. The findings have been brought to the attention of the hospital management to help them to tighten controls. Similar audits will be carried out in the other Government hospitals.
